When a small group of living beings (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it originated (for example, if it moves over a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return), it often finds itself in a different environment from the one it was in before.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a powerful competitor compared to what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all, they still need the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to look less and less like the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they will no longer be considered to belong to the same species.
We call this process "speciation," which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense in which the destiny of humanity is dictated by an underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: the development of technology itself proceeds beyond cultural and political influences, and technology has an impact on societies conditioned intrinsically rather than socially.
For example, we could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, so new methods of production are developed to reduce the cost of owning a car.
Massive car ownership also leads to a higher incidence of accidents on the roads, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat the physical injuries.

Germany was a common enemy during World War II, which led to cooperation between the USSR and the United States. At the end of the war, the deep differences between their different systems, methods and cultures ended the cooperation between these two countries.
Two years after the end of the war, the former allies had become enemies and the Cold War had begun.
It would last for the next 40 years and would see real battles, through the use of proxy armies, on battlefields in Africa, Asia, Afghanistan, Cuba, and many other places.
On September 17, 1939, the Polish defense was already broken, and the only hope was to retreat and reorganize along the Romanian bridgehead.

But these plans became obsolete almost overnight, when more than 800,000 Soviet Red Army soldiers arrived and created the Belorussian and Ukrainian fronts after invading the eastern regions of Poland, violating the Riga Peace Treaty, the Soviet-Polish non-aggression pact, and other international treaties, whether bilateral or multilateral.
The use of ships to transport cargo is by far the most efficient way to move large quantities of people and goods across the oceans.

Traditionally, the navy's job has been to ensure that your country maintains the ability to move your people and your goods, while interfering with your enemy's ability to move their people and their goods.

One of the most remarkable recent examples of this situation was the North Atlantic campaign during World War II. The Americans were trying to cross the Atlantic Ocean to send soldiers and equipment to help Britain.
At the same time, the German navy, primarily using submarines, was trying to stop this traffic.
If the Allies had failed, Germany would probably have conquered Great Britain as it did the rest of Europe.
It seems that goats were domesticated for the first time about 10,000 years ago in the Zagros Mountains of Iran.
Ancient cultures and tribes began to keep them close by for easy access to milk, hair, meat, and hides.

Domesticated goats were generally kept in herds that roamed the hills or other grazing areas, often cared for by shepherds who were usually children or adolescents, similar to the more common term of shepherds. These pastoral methods are still in use today.
Wagonways were built in England as early as the 16th century.

Although the wagon ways were simply made up of parallel wooden planks, they allowed the horses that pulled them to reach greater speeds and to pull heavier loads than on the slightly more accident-prone roads of the day.
Cross-ties were introduced early on to keep the tracks in place. However, it was soon realized that the tracks would be more efficient if they were equipped with a rail on top.
It has become a common practice, but the iron caused more wear on the wooden wheels of the wagons.
Finally, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first iron rails appeared.
The first means of locomotion was walking: humans began walking upright about two million years ago with the arrival of the Homo Erectus ("upright man").
Their predecessors, the australopiths, did not walk upright as usual.
There are bipedal specializations in the fossils of Australopithecus from 4.2 to 3.9 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus may have been walking on two legs as early as seven million years ago.
We can start by living in better harmony with the environment, we can join the environmental movement, and we can even campaign to alleviate future suffering.
In many cases, it is a symptomatic treatment. However, if we don't just want a temporary solution, we need to find the root of the problem and disable it.

It is clear that the world has changed a lot thanks to the scientific and technological advances made by humans, and that the problems have become more important due to the overpopulation and extravagant lifestyle of humanity.

After its adoption by Congress on July 4, a handwritten document signed by Congress President John Hancock and Secretary Charles Thomson was then sent to a few streets away, to the printing shop of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, today known as "Dunlap Broadsides".
The first public reading of the document was given by John Nixon in the Independence Hall courtyard on July 8.
One of them was sent to George Washington on July 6, who read it to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy arrived in London on August 10.
Of the 25 Dunlap broadsides that we know still exist, they are the oldest copies of the document. The original manuscript has not survived.
Many paleontologists believe today that a group of dinosaurs survived and are still alive. They are called birds.
Few people consider them dinosaurs because they have wings and can fly.
But there are many things about birds that still resemble dinosaurs.
They have legs covered with scales and equipped with claws, they lay eggs and walk on their two hind legs like T-Rex.
Practically all computers used today are based on the manipulation of information that is coded in binary form.
A binary number can only have one of two values: 0 or 1. These numbers are called binary digits, or bits in computer jargon.
An internal poisoning may not be visible immediately. Symptoms, such as vomiting, are so general that an immediate diagnosis cannot be made.
The best indicator of an internal poisoning is probably the presence of an open container of medications or household chemicals that are toxic.
Consult the label for specific first aid instructions for this poison.
The term "insect" is used by entomologists in a formal sense for this group of insects.
This term derives from an old familiarity with bedbugs, which are very well adapted to parasitize humans.
Like bed bugs, they are nidicolous, meaning they are adapted to live in the nest or habitat of their host.
In the United States, there are approximately 400,000 cases of multiple sclerosis (MS), which makes it the most common neurological disease among young and middle-aged adults.
Multiple sclerosis is a disease that affects the central nervous system, composed of the brain, spinal cord, and optic nerve.
Research has shown that women are two times more likely to have multiple sclerosis than men.
A couple can very well estimate that it is not in their interest, nor in the interest of the child, to take care of the education of a baby.
These couples can choose to adopt their baby.
In the context of adoption, the biological parents terminate their parental rights so that another couple can raise the child.
The main goal of science is to understand how the world works through the scientific method. This method guides most scientific research.

However, it is not the only one, experimentation, and an experiment is a test that eliminates one or more possible hypotheses, poses questions and makes observations, but also directs scientific research.

Aristotle's opinions on all scientific matters, including psychology, have been accepted.
With the decline of knowledge of Greek, the West has been cut off from its philosophical and scientific roots in Greek.
Many rhythms observed in physiology and behaviour depend on the presence of endogenous cycles and their production by biological clocks.
Periodic rhythms, which are not simply responses to periodic external stimuli, have been documented for most living things, including bacteria, fungi, plants, and animals.
Biological clocks are self-sufficient oscillators that will continue to function for a certain period of time, even in the absence of external stimulation.
The Hershey and Chase experiment was one of the main indications that DNA was a genetic material.
Hershey and Chase used phages, or viruses, to implant their own DNA into a bacterium.
They conducted two experiments to mark either the DNA of the phage with radioactive phosphorus, or the protein of the phage with radioactive sulfur.
Mutations can have many different effects depending on the type of mutation, the importance of the part of the genetic material affected, and if the affected cells are germ cells.
Only mutations in germ cells can be passed on to children, while other mutations can cause cell death or cancer.
Eco-tourism interests people who want to visit natural areas to enjoy the scenery, especially the wildlife and flora.
Hunting, fishing, photography, bird watching, visiting parks, and studying information about the ecosystem are examples of activities on site.
You can, for example, go see, photograph, and discover the orang-outans of Borneo.
Every morning, people leave the small towns of the countryside in their cars to go to their place of work and cross other people who are going to work in the countryside they have just left.
In this dynamic transportation system, everyone is in some way connected to a transportation system based on private cars and supports it.
Science now shows that this economy based on carbon has displaced the biosphere from its state of stability that has supported human evolution for two million years.
Everyone is part of society and uses the transport systems. Almost everyone complains about the transport systems.
In developed countries, it is rare to hear so many complaints about the quality of water or the collapse of bridges.
Why do transportation systems generate so many complaints, why do they break down daily? Are transportation engineers simply incompetent? Or is something more fundamental going on?
Traffic flow is the study of the movements of drivers and vehicles between two points, and the interactions they have with each other.
Unfortunately, it is difficult to study the flow of traffic because the behavior of drivers cannot be predicted with 100 percent certainty.
Fortunately, drivers tend to act within a reasonable range; thus, traffic flows tend to have a reasonable coherence and can be mathematically approximated.
To better represent the traffic flow, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) the flow rate, (2) density and (3) speed.
These relations help with planning, design, and operation of road facilities.
Insects were the first animals to fly. Their ability to fly allowed them to escape their enemies more easily and find food and mates more efficiently.
Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings along their bodies.
It gives them more places to hide from predators.
Today, the only insects that cannot fold their wings are dragonflies and mayflies.
A few thousand years ago, a man named Aristarchus claimed that the solar system revolved around the Sun.
Some thought he was right, but many believed the opposite: that the solar system revolved around the Earth, including the Sun (and even other stars).
This seems reasonable, because the Earth doesn't seem to be moving, does it?
The Amazon River is the second longest and largest river on Earth. It carries more than eight times the volume of the second largest river.
The Amazon is also the largest river in the world, sometimes reaching 10 km wide.
No less than 20% of the water that flows from rivers into the oceans comes from the Amazon.
The main arm of the Amazon River is 6,387 km (3,980 miles) long. It collects water from thousands of small rivers.
Although the construction of stone pyramids continued until the end of the Old Kingdom, the pyramids of Giza were never surpassed in size and technical excellence.
The ancient Egyptians of the New Kingdom were amazed by the monuments of their predecessors, who had been around for more than a thousand years.
The Vatican has about 800 inhabitants. It is the smallest independent country in the world, and the least populated.
The Vatican City drafts its legislation and official communications in Italian.
Italian is also the everyday language used by most people who work for the state, while Latin is often used in religious ceremonies.
All citizens of the Vatican City are Catholic.

It was not so much the four states of matter (in the same order) : solid, liquid, gas and plasma, although he also put forth the theory that these latter substances transform into new substances to form what we see.

Elements like calcium and potassium are considered metals. Of course, there are also metals like silver and gold.
There are also alloys that contain a small amount of non-metallic elements, such as carbon.

The surface of the moon is made up of rocks and dust. Its outer layer is called the crust.
The thickness of the crust is about 70 km on the visible side and 100 km on the hidden side.
It is thinner at sea level and thicker under the continents.
There may be more lava on the near side because the crust is thinner. It was easier for the lava to reach the surface.
Content theories focus on what makes people feel good or what attracts them.
These theories suggest that people have certain needs and/or desires that have been internalized as they mature into adulthood.
These theories examine what motivates some people to do what they do and what, in their environment, motivates them to do or not do certain things.
Two theories of popular content are Maslow's hierarchy of needs and Herzberg's two-factor theory.
In general, two behaviors can emerge when a manager becomes the boss of former colleagues. At one end of the spectrum is to try to remain "the good buddy" (or "the good pal").
This type of manager has a hard time making unpopular decisions, taking disciplinary action, conducting evaluations, delegating responsibilities, and holding others accountable.
At the other end of the spectrum, one transforms into an unrecognizable individual who feels that he/she must change everything that the group has created so far and do things his/her way.
After all, the coach is ultimately responsible for the success and failure of the team.
This behavior often leads to disputes between the leaders and the rest of the team.
Virtual teams are subject to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
Members of a virtual team often function as a point of contact for their immediate physical group.
They often have more autonomy than traditional team members because their teams can meet according to different time zones, which may not be understood by their local management.
The presence of a real "invisible team" (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) is also a unique element of a virtual team.
The "invisible team" is the management team to which each member reports. They set the standards for each of them.

Why would an organization want to go through the tedious process of creating a learning structure? One of the objectives linked to the implementation of organizational learning concepts is innovation.
When all available resources are used effectively in the functional services of an organization, creativity and ingenuity can fully express themselves.
Therefore, the process of an organization working together to overcome an obstacle can lead to a new process innovating to meet the needs of the customer.
Before an organization can be innovative, its leadership must create a culture of innovation, shared knowledge, and its own learning culture.

Neurobiological data provide material evidence for a theoretical approach to the study of cognition. They therefore allow the field of research to be narrowed and made much more precise.
The correlation between brain pathology and behavior supports scientists in their research.
We have known for a long time that different types of brain damage, lesions, tumors and traumas affect behavior and cause changes in certain mental functions.
The emergence of new technologies allows us to see and study brain structures and processes never seen before.
It gives us a lot of information and material to build simulation models that help us understand the processes in our mind.

Although Artificial Intelligence is often strongly connoted with science fiction, it represents a very important part of computer science that studies the intelligent behavior, learning and adaptation of a machine.
Artificial Intelligence research aims to automate tasks requiring intelligent approaches.
Examples include control, planning and programming, the ability to respond to diagnostics and customer questions, as well as recognition of handwriting, voice and face.
These practices have led to distinct disciplines focused on providing solutions to everyday problems.
Artificial intelligence is now often used in the fields of economics, medicine, engineering, and the military, as it has been incorporated into several computer software and video games.
Field trips are an integral part of any school class. Often, a teacher would like to take his or her students to places where a bus trip is not possible.

The solution is provided by technology in the form of virtual field trips. Students can view ancient artifacts in a museum, visit an aquarium, or admire a beautiful work of art while sitting with their class.
Participating in a practical excursion is also an excellent way to reflect on a trip and share experiences with future generations.

For example, students from Bennet High School in North Carolina design a website each year about their visit to the state capital. Each year, the site is updated, but the old versions are kept online to serve as an album.
Blogs can also help students improve their writing skills. Even though students often try blogging with poor grammar and spelling, having an audience generally improves the situation.
As students are often the most critical audience, the blog author is trying to improve his writing to avoid criticism.
In addition, blogging "forces students to better know the world around them." The need to attract the public's attention encourages students to be intelligent and interesting (Toto, 2004).
Blogs are a tool that stimulates collaboration and encourages students to extend their learning beyond the traditional school day.

"When used properly, blogs "can help students strengthen their analytical and critical thinking skills: by reacting actively to online content, they can confront their opinions with those of others and expose their own views on well-defined topics" (Oravec, 2002)."
Ottawa is the charming bilingual capital of Canada and has a large number of art galleries and museums that showcase the past and present of Canada.
You'll find more to the south the Niagara Falls and to the north, the Muskoka region and its surroundings which possess a natural beauty unspoiled.
All these measures, and many more, make Ontario what foreigners consider to be the quintessence of Canada.
Large areas to the north are sparsely populated and some are almost uninhabited in their natural state.
For a comparison that surprises more than one: There are more Afro-Americans living in the United States than Canadian citizens.
The islands of East Africa are located in the Indian Ocean, off the eastern coast of Africa.
Madagascar is by far the largest country, and even a continent in its own right, when it comes to fauna.
Most of the smaller islands are independent nations, or associated with France, and are known for their luxury resorts.
The Arabs also brought the practice of Islam to the land and this religion has spread widely to the Comoros and Mayotte.
European influence and colonialism began in the 15th century when the Portuguese explorer Vasco de Gama discovered the route to the Cape of Good Hope which connects Europe to India.
To the north, the region is delimited by the Sahel, and to the south and west by the Atlantic Ocean.

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BC, and was used by the Phoenicians, the Romans and the Merinides as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who had destroyed it and then rebuilt it and renamed it Casa Branca, finally abandoned it in 1755 after an earthquake.
The Moroccan sultan rebuilt the city under the name Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in all of Morocco for shopping.

Around the old medina, it is easy to find places where you can buy traditional Moroccan products, such as tagines, pottery, leather goods, hookahs, and all sorts of trinkets, but that is all for tourists.
Goma is a tourist town in the extreme east of the Democratic Republic of Congo, near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava from the volcano Nyiragongo which buried most of the streets of the city, particularly the downtown area.
Although Goma is reasonably safe, any visit outside of Goma should be researched to understand the state of the ongoing fighting in the North Kivu province.
The city is also the starting point for the ascent of the volcano Nyiragongo as well as for hiking treks among the cheapest gorilla treks in Africa.
You can use boda-boda (motorcycle taxi) to get around in Goma. The normal (local) price is about 500 Congolese francs for a short ride.
Combined with its relative inaccessibility, "Timbuktu" has become a metaphor for distant and exotic countries.
Today, Timbuktu is a poor city, although its reputation makes it a tourist attraction, and it has an airport.
In 1990, it was added to the list of World Heritage Sites in Danger due to the threat of desert sands.
It was one of the main stops on Henry Louis Gates's PBS series "Wonders of the African World".
The city contrasts sharply with the rest of the country, as it has an Arabic style rather than African.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in northeastern South Africa and borders the Mozambique border to the east, the Zimbabwe border to the north and the Crocodile River forms the southern border.
The total area of the park is 19,500 km², it is divided into 14 ecozones, each with its own unique fauna.
It is one of the most famous amusement parks in South Africa and considered the jewel of South Africa's national parks (SANParks).
As with all South African National Parks, there are daily entrance and conservation fees for the park.
It may be advantageous to obtain a Wild Card that gives access to some parks in South Africa, as well as to all South African national parks.
The island of Hong Kong gives its name to the territory of Hong Kong and is the main attraction for many tourists.
The row of buildings that draws the horizon of Hong Kong has been compared to a bar graph, which is reflected in the waters of Victoria Harbour.
To admire the most beautiful panoramas of Hong Kong, leave the island and head to the waterfront of Kowloon located across the way.
The vast majority of urban development on Hong Kong Island is concentrated on the north shore.
It is the place that the British colonists invested in. Thus, it seems to be a good starting point if you are looking for evidence of the colonial past of this region.
The Sundarbans are the largest coastal mangrove forest in the world, stretching 80 km (50 miles) from the coast to the Bangladeshi and Indian hinterland.
The Sundarbans have been declared a World Heritage Site by the UNESCO. The Indian portion of the forest is called the Sundarbans National Park.
The forests, however, are not composed solely of mangrove swamps: they also contain some of the last remnants of the majestic jungles that once covered the Ganges plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 square kilometers, of which about one-third is covered by swamps/marshes.
Sundarbans is a nature reserve since 1966, you can find about 400 Bengal tigers and 30,000 spotted deer there.

Buses depart from the inter-district bus terminal (located on the other side) throughout the day, but most, particularly those serving the east and Jakar/Bumthang, depart between 6:30 and 7:30 in the morning.
Inter-district buses are often full, so it's recommended to buy a ticket a few days in advance.
Most districts are served by small Japanese ferries, which are comfortable and sturdy.
Shared taxis are a quick and comfortable way to get to nearby places such as Paro (150 Nu) and Punakha (200 Nu).
The Oyapock Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River to link the towns of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges-de-l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
The two towers are 83 meters tall; it is 378 meters long and has two lanes 3.5 meters wide.
The vertical clearance under the bridge is 15 meters. The structure was completed in August 2011, but was not opened to traffic until March 2017.
The bridge should be fully operational by September 2017, when the Brazilian customs posts should be completed.
The Guaraní were the largest indigenous group living in what is now the eastern Paraguay, living as semi-nomadic hunters and practicing subsistence agriculture.
Other indigenous tribes that populated the Chaco, such as the Guaycurú or the Payaguá, survived primarily through fishing, hunting, or gathering.
In the 16th century, Paraguay, formerly known as "the giant province of the Indies", was born from the meeting between Spanish conquerors and indigenous populations.
The Spaniards inaugurated the period of colonization, which lasted three centuries.
Since the founding of Asuncion in 1537, Paraguay has managed to retain a great deal of its indigenous character and identity.
Argentina is known for having one of the best teams and among the best polo players in the world.
The biggest tournament of the year takes place in December on the polo fields of Las Cañitas.
In addition, smaller tournaments and matches are sometimes organized here at other times of the year.
For information on tournaments and places to buy tickets for polo matches, consult the Argentine Polo Association.
The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Islands pound (FKP) whose value is equivalent to a British pound (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank in the islands located in Stanley, opposite the FIC West store.
The pound sterling is a commonly accepted currency throughout the islands, while at Stanley, credit cards and American dollars are also often accepted.
On nearby islands credit cards are unlikely to be accepted, even if it is possible that British and American currencies will be. Speak to the owners in advance to agree on a payment method.
It is almost impossible to exchange money from the Falkland Islands outside the islands, so change it before you leave the islands.
Montevideo being located south of the Equator, winter in the northern hemisphere corresponds to summer there and vice versa.
Montevideo is located in a subtropical zone and summer temperatures exceeding 30 °C are common.
Winter can be deceptively cold: temperatures rarely drop below zero, but the wind and humidity combine to give the impression that it's colder than the thermometer says.
There are not really "rainy" and "dry" seasons: precipitation is fairly constant throughout the year.
Although many of the park's animals are used to seeing humans, they are still wild animals; please do not feed or disturb them.
According to the park authorities, you must stay at least 100 meters from bears and wolves and 25 meters from all other wild animals!
As docile as they may seem, the bison, elk, moose, bear and almost all large animals can attack.
Each year, dozens of visitors are injured because they did not maintain a sufficient distance. These animals are large, wild, and potentially dangerous, so give them space.
In addition, know that odours attract bears and other wild animals, so avoid transporting or cooking odorous foods and keep the camp clean.
Apia is the capital of Samoa. The city is located on the island of Upolu and has a population of less than 40,000.
Apia was founded in the 1850s and is the official capital of Samoa since 1959.
The port was the site of a tragic naval standoff in 1889, when seven German, American and British ships refused to leave the port.
All the ships were sunk, except for a British cruiser. Nearly 200 Americans and Germans lost their lives.
Supreme Chief Tupua Tamasese Lealofi III was assassinated during a peaceful rally that was taking place in the city, during the Mau independence movement.
There are many beaches because Auckland is on two harbors. The most popular are in three areas.
The North Shore beaches (in the North Harbour district) are on the Pacific Ocean and extend from Long Bay to Devonport.
Almost all beaches are sandy and safe for swimming, and most are shaded by pohutukawa trees.
The beaches of Tamaki Drive are located on the Waitemata Harbour in the chic suburbs of Mission Bay and St Heliers in central Auckland.
These beaches, sometimes very popular with families, are lined with shops along the coast. Swimming there is safe.

Travel agencies often have agreements with specific hotels, but you can also book through travel agencies other types of accommodation, such as campgrounds.
Most travel agencies offer packages that include breakfast, transportation to and from the airport, or even packages that combine the flight and the hotel.
They can also hold the reservation for you if you need time to think about the offer or to get other documents necessary for your destination (for example, a visa).

Anyone who travels by car to high latitudes or crosses mountain passes should consider the possibility of snow, ice or glacial temperatures.
On icy and snow-covered roads, friction is low and you can't drive as if you were on a bare road.
During blizzards, it can snow enough in a very short time to block you in.
Visibility can also be limited by snowfalls or dust or condensation or ice on the windows of vehicles.
On the other hand, the presence of ice and snow is normal in many countries, and traffic is virtually uninterrupted all year round.
Safaris may be the biggest tourist attraction in Africa and the most memorable moment for many visitors.

In everyday language, the term 'safari' refers to an African land excursion, and in particular in the savannah, with the aim of witnessing the spectacular sight of wild animals in their natural habitat.
Some animals, such as elephants and giraffes, have a tendency to approach vehicles and standard equipment allows them to be well observed.
Lions, leopards and cheetahs are sometimes shy and you'll see them better with binoculars.
A walking safari (also called "bushwalking", "footing" or "walking safari") consists of hiking, either for a few hours or for several days.

The stirrups are footrests for the rider, which hang on either side of the saddle.
They offer greater stability to the user, but they can pose a security problem: in fact, the user's feet can get stuck in them.
If a rider is thrown from a horse, but has a foot caught in the stirrup, he could be dragged if the horse runs away. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
Firstly, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a smooth and narrow sole.
Then, some saddles, especially English ones, have safety bars that allow a stirrup to fall off the saddle if the rider falls backward.

Europe is a relatively small continent, but with many independent countries. In normal circumstances, traveling through several countries means having to make several visa requests and undergo several passport checks.

Violent weather is the generic term for any meteorological phenomenon that can cause damage, serious social disruption or loss of human life.

Japanese work culture is more hierarchical and formal than that to which Westerners may be accustomed.
